messages.content: What is a credit score?

A credit score is a three-digit number, usually on a scale of 300 to 850, that estimates how likely you are to repay borrowed money and pay bills. Credit scores are calculated from information about your credit accounts. That data is gathered by credit-reporting agencies, also called credit bureaus, and compiled into your credit reports. The three largest bureaus are Equifax, Experian, and TransUnion.
Do I have a single credit score or multiple credit scores?
You don't have a single credit score — you have a few, and they probably vary slightly. That's because two major companies calculate scores and weigh certain credit behaviors differently.
What is the highest credit score one can achieve?
The highest credit score you can get is 850, although there's not much difference between a 'perfect' score and an excellent score when it comes to the rates and products you can qualify for.
What are the general credit score ranges?
A score of 720 or higher is generally considered excellent credit. A score of 690 to 719 is considered good credit. Scores of 630 to 689 are fair credit. And scores of 629 or below are bad credit.
How does FICO break down credit scores?
FICO breaks down credit scores as follows: Below 580 is poor, 580 to 669 is fair, 670 to 739 is good, 740 to 799 is very good, and 800 and above is exceptional.
How does VantageScore break down credit scores?
VantageScore breaks down credit scores as follows: 300 to 600 is subprime, 601 to 660 is near prime, 661 to 780 is prime, and 781 to 850 is superprime.
What factors impact your credit scores the most?

The two things that matter most are payment history and credit utilization. Payment history affects your score if you make late payments, and credit utilization describes how much of your credit limits you are using. It's good to use less than 30% of your credit limits.
What are some additional factors that impact credit scores?

Much less weight goes to these factors, but they still impact your score: credit history, credit mix, and how recently you have applied for credit. The longer you've had credit and the higher the average age of your accounts, the better your score. Scores also reward having more than one type of credit, such as a traditional loan and a credit card.
How can I improve my credit score?

To improve your credit score, pay all bills on time, keep credit card balances under 30% of their limits, keep older credit cards open to protect the average age of your accounts, and space out credit applications over time rather than submitting many in a short period.
Why should I monitor my credit report and score?

Checking your credit score right before you apply for a new loan or credit card can help you understand your chances of qualifying for favorable terms. Checking it ahead of time gives you the chance to improve your score, potentially saving you hundreds or thousands of dollars in interest.
How can I start building credit if I want to get a credit card?
If your aim is to get a credit card, you could start with a secured credit card or co-signed card, or ask to be an authorized user on another person’s card.
How can I build credit without a credit card?

If you want to build credit without a credit card, you might try a credit-builder loan, secured loan, or co-signed loan. There are also ways to use rent, phone, and utility payments to build credit. Some of these methods are free, while others carry a fee.
What is a secured credit card and how does it help build credit?

If you’re building your credit score from scratch or have bad credit, you’ll likely need to start with a secured credit card. A secured card is backed by a cash deposit you make upfront; the deposit amount is usually the same as your credit limit. The purpose of a secured card is to build your credit enough to qualify for an unsecured card with better benefits.
What should I look for in a secured credit card?

Choose a secured card with a low annual fee and make sure it reports payment data to all three credit bureaus, Equifax, Experian, and TransUnion. Cards that report to all three bureaus allow you to build a more comprehensive credit history.
What is a credit-builder loan?

A credit-builder loan is a loan designed to help people build credit. Typically, the money you borrow is held by the lender in an account and not released to you until the loan is repaid. Your payments are reported to credit bureaus, helping you build credit.
What are the responsibilities of a co-signer in building credit?
It’s possible to get a loan or an unsecured credit card using a co-signer. However, the co-signer is responsible for the full amount owed if you don't pay.
How can being an authorized user on another person’s card help build credit?

A family member or significant other may add you as an authorized user on their card. Doing so adds that card's payment history to your credit files, which can help you build credit faster. You don't have to use or possess the credit card to benefit from being an authorized user.
What is required to have a FICO score?

To have a FICO score, you need at least one account that’s been open six months or longer and at least one creditor reporting your activity to the credit bureaus in the past six months. A VantageScore can be generated more quickly.
What good credit habits should I practice to build my credit score?

To build your credit score, make your payments on time, pay at least the minimum, and ideally pay more than the minimum if possible. Keep your credit utilization below 30%, avoid applying for multiple credit accounts close together, and keep credit card accounts open unless there's a compelling reason to close them.
How does credit utilization impact my credit score?

Credit utilization is the percentage of your credit limit you use. Keeping your credit utilization below 30% on all cards is recommended, and the lower your utilization, the better it is for your score.
How can I fix my bad credit?

Fixing bad credit starts with checking your credit report for errors. You can get free credit reports from each of the three major credit bureaus—Experian, TransUnion, and Equifax—through AnnualCreditReport.com. Review accounts, personal information, and credit inquiries for any inaccuracies. Dispute any incorrect information to have it corrected or removed.
What should I look for when reviewing my credit report?

When reviewing your credit report, look for accounts you don't recognize, payments inaccurately reported as late, incorrect credit limits or account balances, and any unauthorized hard inquiries. These could indicate errors or potential fraud.
How do I dispute credit report errors?

To dispute credit report errors, file a dispute with the relevant credit bureau (Experian, TransUnion, or Equifax). You can do this online, by mail, or by phone. The bureau will contact the company that provided the information, and they have 30 days to investigate your claim.
How can I bring past-due accounts current?

If you're late but not yet 30 days behind on a payment, pay it immediately. If the payment is already 30 days or more overdue, bring the account current as soon as possible. Contact the lender to ask about hardship options if you can't afford to make the payment.
Why is setting up autopay important for fixing credit?

Setting up autopay helps ensure you make on-time payments, which is crucial since payment history accounts for 35% of your credit score. You can set up autopay for at least the minimum payment to avoid late payments, but it's best to pay in full if possible.
How does credit utilization impact my credit score, and how can I maintain a low utilization rate?

Credit utilization measures how much revolving credit you use relative to your credit limits, accounting for up to 30% of your credit score. To maintain a low utilization rate, aim to keep your utilization below 30%, and ideally below 10%, to have a positive impact on your credit score.
What are effective strategies to pay off debt and improve credit?

To pay off debt, create a budget to allocate extra money toward high-interest debt. The debt snowball or debt avalanche methods can be effective, or you could consider a debt consolidation loan to simplify payments and potentially reduce interest rates.
Should I apply for new credit while trying to fix my credit score?

Avoid applying for new credit while fixing your credit score, as each application triggers a hard inquiry, which can temporarily lower your score. If you must apply, use a tool like Experian's comparison tool to find loans you're likely to qualify for.
Is it beneficial to keep unused credit accounts open?

Yes, keeping unused credit accounts open is generally beneficial because it helps with your credit utilization rate and maintains the length of your credit history, both of which positively impact your credit score. Only close accounts if there's a compelling reason, such as a high annual fee.
How can a secured credit card help fix bad credit?

A secured credit card requires a refundable security deposit and is easier to obtain with poor credit. Use it for small purchases and pay off the balance in full every month to demonstrate responsible credit usage, which can help improve your credit score.
What is a credit-builder loan, and how can it help improve credit?

A credit-builder loan is designed to help people build or rebuild credit. The money you borrow is kept in an account until the loan is repaid. Making timely payments helps demonstrate financial responsibility, and your payment history is reported to credit bureaus, which can improve your credit score.
Should I seek credit counseling if I'm struggling with fixing my credit?

Yes, working with a nonprofit credit counseling agency can help you create a plan to manage your finances and pay off debt. The National Foundation for Credit Counseling (NFCC) and the Financial Counseling Association of America are good places to find certified credit counselors.
What online tools can I use to monitor my credit report and score?

You can use AnnualCreditReport.com to get free weekly credit reports from the major bureaus. Many banks and credit card providers also offer free credit score tracking. Experian Boost® is a tool that can help boost your score by considering on-time payment of bills not normally reported to credit bureaus.
How can establishing positive financial habits help rebuild credit?

Establishing positive financial habits, such as paying bills on time, maintaining low credit utilization, and avoiding unnecessary credit applications, can significantly improve your credit score over time. These habits contribute to a stronger credit profile and better financial health.
How can a balance transfer card help fix my credit?

If you're struggling with high-interest credit card debt, consider a balance transfer credit card. These cards typically offer an introductory 0% APR for nine to 21 months, allowing you to consolidate high-interest debt onto one card. This can save you money on interest and simplify payments. Ensure you can pay off the balance within the promotional period to avoid further debt.
How do I calculate the monthly payments for a balance transfer card?

To calculate how much to allocate toward the balance each month, divide the transferred balance by the number of months in the promotional period. Remember to include the balance transfer fee, typically 3% to 5% of the transferred balance, which is added to the total balance.
Should I close old credit cards after paying them off?

Avoid closing old credit cards, even if you don't plan to use them, as it can lower your credit score. Credit history length makes up 15% of your credit score, and the longer your history, the better. Instead, consider putting a recurring expense on the card to keep it active and pay it off in full and on time.
What should I do if I don't want to use an old credit card but don't want it closed?

If you don't want to use an old credit card, hide it in a safe place to prevent use, or put a small recurring charge on it, such as a subscription service, and pay it off in full each month. This keeps the account active without increasing your debt.
Is it ever a good idea to close a credit card?

It may be a good idea to close a credit card if it has an annual fee and you no longer plan to use it. However, be aware that closing a card can negatively impact your credit utilization and credit history length.
